thread.title: Crackdown on bad bosses wouldn't have stopped Sports Direct problems, say Labour
thread.title_full: Crackdown on bad bosses wouldn't have stopped Sports Direct problems, say Labour

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Crackdown on bad bosses wouldn't have stopped Sports Direct problems, say Labour
text:
Crackdown on bad bosses wouldn't have stopped Sports Direct problems, say Labour Government launches plans to improve the way businesses are run including a crackdown on excessive pay deals Share Mike Ashley (Photo: Joe Giddens/PA Wire) Share Get daily   
Labour have criticised Government plans to give workers a say in how businesses are run by warning they wouldn’t have stopped the problems seen at Sports Direct. 
Shadow Business Secretary highlighted Sports Direct, part-owned by Toon boss Mike Ashley , and former high street shopping chain BHS. 
He was responding to the publication of a review into the way businesses operate, including a crackdown on excessive pay deals. 
Proposals include forcing businesses to be more open about the pay received by their top executives, for example by requiring them to reveal how the pay of the chief executive compares to the pay of the average worker in the firm. 
Other ideas include creating advisory boards of “stakeholders”, including employees, to advise directors. 
Mr Lewis said he was not wholly convinced the package outlined by ministers would have prevented “the corporate governance scandals that have plagued the last summer”. 
Measures include applying corporate governance standards for public companies - which means their shares are sold openly - to large private companies Sports Direct 
But Mr Lewis said the proposals would do little to improve conditions at firms which are publicly traded such as Sports Direct. Although Mr Ashley holds a majority stake in the business, shares are traded on the London Stock Exchange. 
He said: “To force private companies to abide by the corporate governance code will do little unless that code is tightened. 
“BHS may have been a private company, but Sports Direct isn’t, and we all know what has gone on there.” 
Earlier this year, an inquiry by MPs condemned “appalling working practices” at Sports Direct, including the use of agency staff on temporary contracts, so that the business does not need to employ them directly, and the use of zero hour contracts in Sports Direct shops, which MPs said meant staff can be “bullied, pushed around, and summarily sacked with no explanation.” 
MPs have also criticised former BHS owner Sir Philip Green, The Commons Business, Innovation and Skills Committee said he sold the retial chain to someone who knew was a “wholly unsuitable purchaser” before its failure, and his family “benefited significantly from BHS” but he failed “to invest sufficiently in stores or reinvent the business to beat the prevailing high street competition”. Former BHS owner Sir Philip Green 
Launching a green paper setting out the Government’s proposals in a statement to the Commons, Business Secretary Greg Clark told MPs: “The document asks whether there are measures which could increase the connection between boards of directors of companies and their employees and customers. 
“It asks whether the establishment of advisory panels and the appointment of designated non-executive directors to take formal responsibility for articulating employee, customer and other perspectives is the right way to proceed. We are not prescribing how this should be done. It would be whatever is most appropriate for each business.” 
Mr Clark said that other reforms responded to the fact that “executive pay has grown much faster over the last two decades than pay generally and at times is not in line with corporate performance”. Read More Sports Direct to be probed by financial reporting watchdog 
“The document seeks views on this issue, in particular how to strengthen shareholder voting rights with a view to making them binding; encouraging shareholder engagement with executive pay and promoting greater transparency over pay,” he said. 
And he confirmed that the Government is seeking “views on whether some of the features of corporate governance which have served us well in our listed companies should be extended to the largest privately held companies”. Chi Onwurah 
Mr Clark said that the UK continued to have some of the tightest corporate governance rules in the world, and said concerns related to “a very small number of businesses which have undermined the reputation of British business generally”. 
Josh Hardie, CBI Deputy Director-General, said: “The UK’s approach to corporate governance is respected around the world. British firms know that great relationships with staff, customers and communities is the cornerstone of success. 
“However, businesses agree that legitimate concerns exist and are determined that the unacceptable behaviour of the few should not tarnish the effectiveness of the many. 
“So it is right that approaches to governance continue to evolve to support a modern, fair economy. 
“We look forward to working with Government to finding solutions that enhance the UK’s governance framework.” 
Newcastle Central Labour MP Chi Onwurah said: “The Government’s consultation on corporate governance is a half hearted, disappointing affair which will not support best business practice, fit businesses for the future or put workers on the boards. 
“Having alienated business with the absence of any Brexit plan, Mrs May does not feel able to challenge them to deliver what the British people want to see on pay, diversity or worker representation. This is a weak, failing Government.” Like us on Facebook
